content: If you were a professor, you would rather teach a course involving subjectivity and opinions (literature, philosophy, art), rather than something like math, science, engineering, or economics.
You value someone’s respect over their love.
You follow your heart, rather than your head.
You base your sense of morality on justice, rather than compassion.
The climate movement needs more storytellers, rather than problem solvers. (Or, alternatively, the climate crisis is a people problem, rather than a technology problem.)
You are more moved by facts and figures about a social issue than emotional stories about that issue.
People describe you as logical and pragmatic.
Your interest in the climate movement comes primarily from a place of empathy.
Seeing someone else cry can cause you to cry as well.
You often act based on a “feeling,” even if you can’t quite put it into words.
If you wanted to learn more about the climate movement, you would rather go to a conference and meet folks as opposed to doing some research independently.
In group settings, you find that you get introduced more than you introduce others.
You require alone time to recharge.
You value knowing and meeting a lot of people.
The thought of meeting new people excites you more than it intimidates you.
You find parties more draining than energizing.
You have been described as quiet, shy, or reserved.
In your downtime, you feel the urge to socialize or spend time with friends.
Your ideal birthday party involves a few close friends and/or family, as opposed to a large group of friends.
You would rather write a paper or article about the climate crisis than give a TED Talk about the climate crisis.
Given the choice, you’d rather write an essay than take a multiple choice test.
When you consume a piece of art (a movie, a painting, a song), you think about how you would have done it differently/similarly.
You think that rules are meant to be broken.
You think that the solution(s) to the climate crisis already exist and we’re just not doing them—there’s no real need to come up with new solutions.
A blank page excites you more than it intimidates you.
You like to express yourself by making things.
Whether it’s writing, painting, building, etc.—you often have the urge to create things.
If money was of no concern, you would rather move into a beautifully furnished apartment instead of picking out the furniture for yourself.
You would rather carry out an established plan, as opposed to formulating the plan.
When you’re cooking, you treat recipes more as inspiration than as instructions.
